name: Melatonin
summary: Melatonin is a naturally occurring hormone produced by the pineal gland that regulates circadian rhythms and sleep-wake cycles. Supplementation is widely used for insomnia, jet lag, and circadian rhythm disorders.
description: Melatonin is an endogenous indoleamine synthesized from serotonin in the pineal gland, primarily secreted at night. As a supplement, it is used for sleep initiation, jet lag, shift work sleep disorder, and circadian rhythm disturbances. Beyond sleep, melatonin has antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective properties, and has been investigated in psychiatric and neurodegenerative conditions. It is generally considered safe, non-habit forming, and well tolerated at standard doses.

metadata.natural_source: Pineal gland secretion (synthetic form used in supplements)
metadata.prescription_status: OTC supplement in most countries; prescription required in some (e.g., UK, EU for higher doses)

contraindications: Pregnancy and breastfeeding (safety not fully established)
Autoimmune disorders (theoretical risk of immune modulation)

sections.text: Melatonin binds to MT1 and MT2 receptors in the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus, regulating circadian rhythms and promoting sleep initiation. It also exerts antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects.

items: Adjunctive use in anxiety or depression (off-label)

adult.range: 0.5–10 mg depending on indication and individual sensitivity

sections.pediatric: 0.5–3 mg at bedtime for circadian rhythm disorders or insomnia (with medical supervision)

sections.text: Onset: 30–60 minutes. Duration: 4–8 hours depending on formulation (immediate vs extended release).

other: May cause daytime sedation if taken late at night or in high doses.
Caution with long-term use in children—safety not well established.

sections.pediatrics: May be used short-term under medical supervision for sleep/circadian disorders
sections.geriatrics: Effective and safe; often used for insomnia and circadian rhythm disorders

sections.text: Generally no tapering required; melatonin is not habit-forming. Gradual reduction may be helpful for those on long-term high-dose use.

items: Extended-release formulations are useful for sleep maintenance insomnia.
Lower doses (0.5–1 mg) may be as effective as higher doses for circadian shifting.
Non-pharmacological sleep hygiene measures should be combined with supplementation.
